Award.AwardTitle: Aspects of Sofic Entropy and Algebraic Actions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mathematical theory of dynamical systems concerns itself with states of certain physical systems (e.g., the amount of a certain gas inside a room, the population of a species, the temperature inside a building) as they evolve in time. It happens to be useful and natural to make "time" itself more abstract and replace it with any other discrete system of symmetries, say of some object (such symmetries form what is a called a discrete group). In the case of a very chaotic physical system, one cannot effectively predict its future state. This fact gives rise to an important quantity, the entropy of the system, that measures how unpredictable it is. Entropy was originally defined directly within an information theoretic context, but it turns out that, if one views it instead from the perspective of a statistical mechanics formalism, the scope of entropy theory is increased to encompass a very large class of groups known as "sofic groups." Seen through this new lens, entropy becomes a measurement of how many finitary approximations the physical system has. The general question of how well an infinitary process can be approximated by a finitary one is a fundamental question of scientific inquiry, and the class of sofic groups includes many natural examples coming from geometry and number theory. This project also sheds light on the connection to physics that is inherent in its statistical mechanical and information theoretic origins. Moreover, the subject has proven to have interesting links to diverse areas of mathematics, including the following: functional analysis, ergodic theory, combinatorics, and operator algebras. Many of the links are direct consequences of the principal investigator's research. The project is part of ongoing activity to strengthen and understand such connections.

This project revolves around three main problems. The first is to understand the orbit equivalence consequences of positive or complete positive entropy for actions of nonamenable groups. For example, the principal investigator has shown that actions with complete positive entropy are strongly ergodic and that positive entropy actions are not weakly compact. He seeks to prove that actions with compete positive entropy are solidly ergodic, as defined by Chifan and Ioana, which will give further indication of the Bernoulli-like behavior that these actions exhibit. Part of the interest in this objective is that it places the theory of entropy for actions of nonamenable groups in stark contrast to the study of entropy for actions of amenable groups, where it is impossible to derive any orbit equivalence consequences of entropy. These consequences of complete positive entropy apply to algebraic actions (i.e., actions on compact groups by automorphisms), for the principal investigator can already demonstrate that algebraic actions related to invertible convolution operators have complete positive entropy. A second problem is concerned with investigating the entropy theory of algebraic actions of equivalence relations, which is joint work with Lewis Bowen and Dylan Airey. One aim of this part of the project is to generalize the principal investigator's results on entropy and Fuglede-Kadison determinants from the group case to the equivalence relation case. Lastly, the principal investigator will further the connections between dynamics and operator algebras by defining sofic entropy for actions on operator algebras.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was concerned with the mathematical theory of dynamical systems, which aims to study certain physical phenomena (e.g. gas inside a room, population of a species, temperature) as it evolves in time. In this case "time" (formulated mathematically as the integers) gets replaced with a discrete system of symmetries (mathematicians call this a group). Of significant interest is the entropy, which is a number measuring the unpredictably of the dynamics, and the class of symmetries are a large class of groups known as "sofic groups".

The intellectual merit of the project includes 8 published papers, as well as four preprints, two of which are under review. Sample journals include higher-level journals such as International Mathematics Research Notices and Analysis & PDE. Results include generalizations of theorems which are fundamental in the integer case to the case of sofic groups, including product formulas for entropy, and a fine study of when algebraic actions have completely positive entropy. The study of algebraic actions may be thought of as the "symmetries of symmetries” and is a rapidly developing field. Part of his work in this area connects to random walks, a natural object in probability.

In joint work with Lewis Bowen and Frank Lin, he also developed what may be the first "genuinely continuous" multiplicative ergodic theorem. The multiplicative ergodic theorem is a result in dynamical systems which of important in the study of differential geometry, a field whose applications include a rigorous framework for Einstein's theory of relativity (among others).

 The methods in this project also apply to the study of von Neumann algebras, mathematical objects which form the basis for quantum mechanics, as well as understanding of problems in Fourier series (which have applications in acoustics, optics, and signal processing and related subjects). Included in these von Neumann algebra applications are results in Popa's deformation/rigidity theory, which aims to recover the starting data (e.g. a group, dynamical system, etc.) of a von Neumann algebra from the algebra itself. This area has strong ties to dynamical systems and group theory, and the PI's work increased the ties to the field of "L2-invariants", which gives geometrical insight into the study of discrete groups.

Other work in von Neumann algebras while being funded by this grant includes surprising connections to random matrices, an area with connections to nuclear physics and theoretical neuroscience, and involves reducing a well-known open problem in von Neumann algebras to a natural random matrix conjecture. 

The broader impacts of this work include broadcasting his results at numerous conferences, including giving a mini-course in Madrid based on his expertise in the field. He also started collaborations which furthered the careers of early-career mathematicians (graduate students and recent doctorates). He participated in many efforts to improve the representation of women and underrepresented minorities in mathematics, attending many events hosted by groups founded to improve the success of underrepresented groups such as the Math Alliance, and the National Association of Mathematicians. He also ran two separate reading courses with undergraduates, Yichen Ma and Luca Scerbo, at the University of Virginia, including a distinguished major thesis, which were instrumental in Yichen and Luca being admitted to doctorate programs in mathematics.
